Resident Evil 7 is one of my favorite entries in the series. It‚Äôs a true reboot that brought back the classic horror and survival atmosphere fans loved in the early games. The story pulls you into the terrifying world of the Baker family, where every step could be your last.

The gameplay change is the biggest shift ‚Äî the series moved to a first-person perspective, making the horror feel closer and more personal. The focus is now on exploration, limited resources, and constant tension, rather than pure action.
This is the game that brought Resident Evil back to life for a reason. The game is awesome!

Resident Evil 7: Biohazard‚Äôs shift in perspective and its Texas-Chain-Saw-Massacre-inspired setting intensify the scaremmersion, with unexpected twists that heighten an already gripping story in a nightmarish return to classic survival horror.

RE 7 was an incredible journey from start to finish. What struck me the most was the psychological depth of the story. The game doesn‚Äôt rely only on jumpscares or gore; instead, it builds an unsettling narrative that slowly gets under your skin. I was fully immersed from the very beginning, and the tension never really let go. Every twist hit at the perfect moment and kept me completely hooked.

The world-building is another major highlight. The environments, small details, and characters all work together to create a story that feels carefully constructed and genuinely thought-provoking. You can feel that every room, note, and encounter has a purpose, and that makes exploring incredibly rewarding.

The DLCs also deserve a mention, they're a must-play. They add great post-game content that feels meaningful rather than just extra filler, and they gave me even more appreciation for the whole game.

If I had to point out one weaker part, it would be the section on the ship. It slows down the pacing and drops a bit of the tension that the game builds so well elsewhere. It‚Äôs not bad, just noticeably less gripping compared to the rest.

Overall, Resident Evil 7 is another excellent entry in the saga. Finishing it at 100% was absolutely worth it, and I‚Äôd highly recommend it to anyone who wants a tense, atmospheric, and memorable horror experience.
A tight, unsettling survival horror. The Baker house is insanely atmospheric and the tension never lets up. A disturbing, memorable experience from start to finish. Must play.

Resident Evil 7: Biohazard marks a bold and terrifying return to the series‚Äô survival horror roots. By shifting to a first-person perspective, the game plunges players directly into the claustrophobic and unsettling world of the Baker family, delivering an intensity and immersion rarely seen in horror games.

The atmosphere is pitch-perfect: every creaking floorboard, shadowy hallway, and grotesque detail contributes to a constant sense of dread. The game‚Äôs visuals and sound design are exceptional, combining to make even familiar settings feel deeply menacing.

Gameplay emphasizes survival and careful strategy. Ammo and resources are scarce, forcing players to think before they act and heightening the tension of every encounter. Puzzles and exploration are intelligently designed, rewarding curiosity while maintaining a constant sense of vulnerability.

The story is gripping and horrifying, blending psychological terror with body horror in a way that feels fresh yet unmistakably Resident Evil. The Baker family, particularly Jack Baker, are unforgettable antagonists whose presence keeps players on edge throughout.

Overall, Resident Evil 7: Biohazard revitalizes the franchise with a terrifying, immersive experience that balances horror, story, and gameplay flawlessly. It‚Äôs a must-play for both longtime fans and newcomers seeking a true survival horror thrill.

Rating: 9.5/10

RE7 is an incredible survival horror game. Of all of the Resident Evil games that I have played, it contains the least action, but is better for it, as it really shines best when exploring its dark, twisted setting. The best section of the game involves going through the large Baker house - a dilapidated estate in Louisiana Bayou. It's a truly inspired setting, and Capcom nailed the Southern Horror vibe incredibly well - it's extremely authentic and believable. The attention to detail is amazing, and it's the most memorable haunted house/house of horrors setting in any media that I've been exposed to. The story is excellent, and very intriguing, as you piece together why Ethan is there, what's really going on, and what happened to the Baker family. They're extremely memorable villains and very menacing as well. Also, even nearly 9 years after release, at the time of writing, the game looks incredible. Up close, some of the character models are showing age, but in the moment-to-moment, the visual fidelity is awesome and the performance is incredible. I also enjoyed the 1st person setting much more than I thought I would - I think it's absolutely necessary for the kind of game they crafted, and it is more immersive than the 3rd person RE games, by necessity, as that's really what you're getting here - a very engaging and immersive horror experience.

There's a lot to say about this game. Firstly, its not like any other Resident Evil game, it's so far from the familiarity of heavy action-packed gameplay and instead focusses solely on horror, horror and horror. Biohazard 7 truly broke the mould (no pun intended) of what everyone knew the franchise was about. Aesthetically, gameplay-wise, narratively, everything about this has been carefully crafted to be it's own independent story without too much reference to the other games. This is perfect, it's a breath of fresh air and grounds the player in the world that they're in through the eyes of Ethan Winters. We're not just playing as Ethan Winters, we feel like we are Ethan Winters weaving our way through a great story with just the right amount of exposition, tension, action, and emotion.

There are hardcore fans of the Resident Evil franchise who have been there since the beginning and express their discomfort with the new direction this game took. It's so different that it doesn't actually feel like a Resident Evil title, but instead an actual horror game like Silent Hill, Still Wakes the Deep, Find Yourself, etc etc. Whether you like the game or not depends. Do you want another heavily action packed resident evil with boulder-punching Chris Redfield with an ocean of bullets, or do you want something fresh, subtle, with amazing narrative and story?

Personally, I think this is by far the best Resident Evil title ever. Though, that's mostly because the game rejuvenated the franchise and attracted new fans which contributed to the popularity of the remakes and new titles after that. That and the fact that the game is just perfect. It's a beautiful gem. If I had to give first place to any other Resident Evil game, it would be Resident Evil 4 remake, then RE8 Village and then RE2 remake.

[h1] I ASSUME A REAL SURVIVAL‚ÄìHORROR [/h1]
[h2] ‚ÄìPREFACE‚Äì [/h2]
It is been one my favorites for a while, yet i wasn't able to beat it on madhouse difficulty switching back mid game to normal second time of playing, i still think it is quite impressive work in survival-horror terms for its time. Here are my drawbacks and upsides as of stuff which stands out:
[h3] - - - Drawbacks [/h3]
There are few. Related to unskipable cutscenes, blocked backdoors as in classic horror movies, bloody 4 leg molded monster which is not really a drawback rather the thing i do not like, maybe shooting mechanic, and for some people like me MADHOUSE difficulty, especially margaret boss battle in the greenhouse. [h3] If you about to play on madhouse prep yourself heavily for this battle! [/h3]
[h3] + + + Upsides (Now here game shines) [/h3]
[olist]
[*] Instantly sets up classic horror atmosphere with weird video message, arrival by car to abandoned territory, firstly silent atmosphere, stairs scene, then family introduction, that hopeful cop episode and some more.. it all screams classic (think texas chainsaw massacre, saw and maybe even jeepers creepers and outlast game).
[*] Story. It is not much relative to previous games, but separately works perfect or near perfect, thats for i praise ethan winters installments of RE so much, because they work not as resident evil games. Toward the end it gets revealing and even dramatic with flashbacks, jack bakers confession, lab, escape through mines to guest house so geniusly, cinematic transition of eveline to its last form and finally dramatic epic ending. (Damn, even credits made me watch them and listen to that memorable nice go tell aunt rhody song)
[*] Quite gory and amoral scenes with severed leg/hand, gut eating iconic dinner, deputys body rip off, margarett spider mutation and many more.
[*] Bakers estate design. I do not care that much for the rest sections of the game, but the house design with all level content, secret/alter passages and details is a separate respect. Each location has something special and involving about it. One of my definite favorites is lucas' birthday quest, just brilliant.
[*] Stealth mechanic. Which is quite essential in some parts especially on madhouse. It is more or less normally implemented, nothing special, but it nicely fits here.
[*] DLCs. There are various and all nice i think. Some related to branches of story (end of zoe, not a hero, daughters, bedroom), and others are mini-game acrady gameplay alike (jacks's birthday, ethan must die, nightmare, and quite addictive 21). My favs likely are original branch of story with new gameplay mechanics in end of zoe, involving escape quest with margaret in bedroom and for sure deadly gambling of 21.
[*] I could carry on with many points but here are some mechanics or takes i think made this game special: vhs tapes playthroughs, phone calls, saferoom storage for item management, cassettes for saving game on madhouse, coins and bird cages, some puzzles, codex watch, choice between two endings with relatively different consequences and some more..
[/olist]
[h2] ‚ÄìVERDICT‚Äì [/h2]
Briefly, game is full of proper horror design, nicely settled story and ain't cheap gameplay value. Maybe its sequel comes with better visuals, locations, characters and cinematic/epic edges, i think biohazard is doing its job in survival-horror genre much better. My final word is:
[h1] GREAT [/h1]
P.S. [spoiler] I used to give a higher rank to this game much earlier, but upon replaying it on madhouse and being grown, perhaps some perception changed or i just stayed unsatisfied after losing margaret on madhouse, struggling with her for about couple of hours (literally), and then i just switched to normal difficulty save which i thankfully got and completed latter half of the game with second ending. [/spoiler]

This is easily one of my top 10 favorite video games of all time.

I don't know what it is about the Ethan Winters duology, but this game & Resident Evil: Village are just so much fun, each in their own way. I can't recommend this game enough, & if it's your first playthrough, take it slow, look over every detail, search every nook & cranny, read every piece of lore, & I promise you, you will leave satisfied.

Then, you have like 8 different pieces of DLC ranging from really fun Wave minigames to entire prequel Story modes & sequel modes, too. Wondering how all this started? Play Daughters. Wondering what happened afterward? Play Not a Hero & End of Zoe. Wondering what happened to Clancy, the ever-dependable cameraman from the tape at the beginning? Play Nightmare, Bedroom & 21. 

Take my word for it, as a life-long hardcore Resident Evil fan, Resident Evil 7 is a MUST-have, MUST-play title that still gets its worth even hundreds of hours in.

A completely different experience from the previous titles, but still with that Resident Evil feel. Probably the scariest character is still my wife, both in the game and in real life, so I chose to save Zoe. In the end, I had to repeat it so that the DLC and the rest of RE8 would make sense.

Oh boy this game has been dusting for years in my library after finishing it for the first time back 2019, and god damn this game is still so pleasant to play.

Resident Evil 7 is, to me, the scariest Resident Evil to date and the best one of the franchis as an entry as well. The game is short, but really effective (you can finish this game in around 10 hours if you're exploring and reading everything, but fastest for me has been below 4 hours since it is needed for trophies).

The game is quite intense, you follow the story of Ethan Winters, that tries to find your 3 years long gone wife in the middle of Bayou... Out of nowhere ! It seems fishy but that's the intro, the game will show you many gross stuff throughout the game and the ambiance will make you be on alert at every corner of that damned house for the entirety of your night there. There is some actions next to the survival-puzzle-horror aspect that is really good, and to dig into replayability you'll have the "wonderful" trophies and the DLCs that actually deserves their price (Nightmares my beloved). 

But what got me back into this game and pulled me beneath the water with this game, was all the lore, the story, the characters and the really strong feeling of "why am I here in the first place ?" because in the end of this night, you're just a civilian that got dragged into a really horrible story that gets beyond your understanding, just to, for a slight chance that might be in vain, to find your wife that was presumed dead 3 years back. 
And that made me connect to Ethan, because, I too, have lost significant others, they were there, then the next day it was like they had never existed in the first place, only to find years later a note, or a confession letter telling they left or that they just got **lled. and that link lingered through my whole 3 playthrough, and when the quote of the bad ending came there, I saw myself of the past still searching for those significant others months later their vanishing.

That's what made me want to do that 100%, A link between my story and a Fictional character's story who's just a script behind lines of codes and 3D models. This is what gaming is for me and that is the meaning for me to do a completionninst, just because I love it, and because it resonated with me.

And I hope, if you buy this game after this review*, that you'll be able to link to Ethan, as I did, for another reason or the same ! 

"When one door closes, another opens."
Never get out of the light, be safe y'all :)
Peace

Now that the dust settled on RE2, and more than half a decade passed since i last played RE7, i REALLY notice how all the fun moments of this game take place on a tightly scripted roller coaster. 7 years ago i was terrified and didn't notice at all, but now standing in the one spot that the game allows me to not be seen by "daddy" feels very boring and over-designed. Since RE7 came out about 3 years after Alien Isolation, i really expected there to be a much more open map, or options to fight back against anyone else than the molded. After all, the invincible family promote exactly the same gameplay as the Alien: stalk and hide. 
Amnesia: The Bunker clearly had the same aspirations, and took a tighter designed approach to its core loop with an algorithmically randomized bunker that prompts the player to figure it out on their own, instead of bombarding them with duller and duller chase sequences.

But everytime you are allowed roam around an area at your own pace you are either set up for the next jumpscare (eta <2 minutes), or you just fight molded. Large goo guys. They have big heads that burst open on headshots. They walk as if they have a stick up their ass. And they are veeeery boring, i even remember how dull i found them when i first played it. And unlike the first RE games, there is no real way to walk by them without wasting large amounts of ammo. sad.

I never made it to the ending since i heard that was where the molded stuff peaks, and i feel i've REALLY seen enough of it by now. All the best parts of this game are a tasteless and gory slasher film. Exactly what RE needed at the time, but not what i cherish about the series at all. 2/5

Now that the dust settled on RE2, and more than half a decade passed since i last played RE7, i REALLY notice how all the fun moments of this game take place on a tightly scripted roller coaster. 7 years ago i was terrified and didn't notice at all, but now standing in the one spot that the game allows me to not be seen by "daddy" feels very boring and over-designed. Since RE7 came out about 3 years after Alien Isolation, i really expected there to be a much more open map, or options to fight back against anyone else than the molded. After all, the invincible family promote exactly the same gameplay as the Alien: stalk and hide. 
Amnesia: The Bunker clearly had the same aspirations, and took a tighter designed approach to its core loop with an algorithmically randomized bunker that prompts the player to figure it out on their own, instead of bombarding them with duller and duller chase sequences.

But everytime you are allowed roam around an area at your own pace you are either set up for the next jumpscare (eta <2 minutes), or you just fight molded. Large goo guys. They have big heads that burst open on headshots. They walk as if they have a stick up their ass. And they are veeeery boring, i even remember how dull i found them when i first played it. And unlike the first RE games, there is no real way to walk by them without wasting large amounts of ammo. sad.

I never made it to the ending since i heard that was where the molded stuff peaks, and i feel i've REALLY seen enough of it by now. All the best parts of this game are a tasteless and gory slasher film. Exactly what RE needed at the time, but not what i cherish about the series at all. 2/5
